JavaScript - Arrays

Basic Array Modifiers

Slice — .slice([startIndex],[endIndex])

Slice is an unmuting array method that cuts a part of the original into a new variable.

// consider:
    let arr = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e'];
    
    console.log(arr.slice(2));
    console.log(arr.slice(2, 4));
    
// negative parameters starts at end of the array
    console.log(arr.slice(1, -2));
    console.log(arr.slice(-2));
    console.log(arr.slice(-4, 3));
    
// copy entire array
    console.log(arr.slice());

Splice — .splice([startIndex], [countFromStart])

The splice method is similar to slice, with the difference that it modifies the original array.

console.log(arr.splice(2)); // returns: c d e
    console.log(arr); // a b
    
//Splice to delete last elements:
    console.log(`original: ${arr}\ndeleted with splice: ${arr.splice(-1)}\nleft: ${arr}`);

Reverse — .reverse()

Reverses the order of an array, modifying the original.

Concat — .concat(arr)

An immuting function that sticks 2 arrays or strings together.

const comboArray = arr.concat(arr2);
    
    // Alternatively:
    const comboArraySpread = [...arr, ...arr2];

Join — .join(' ')

This method unmuting joins the content of an array into a string, taking an argument to define the filler between items.

console.log(letters.join('-')); //=> a-b-c-d-e-f-...

Looping Over Arrays

forEach — .forEach(function(cur, i, arr))

The forEach method passes over each item of an array and executes a function defined in its callback method.

The arguments of the forEach callback method are:

  1. the current item,
  2. the current index,
  3. the entire array.

Using for each with maps and sets:

// forEach with Map --------
    // looks like:
    // [map].forEach(function([firstArg: value], [secondArg: key], [thirdArg: entireMap]));
    // consider:
    const currencies = new Map([
      // single map entry key:value
      ['USD', 'United States dollar'],
      // single map entry key:value
      ['EUR', 'Euro'],
      // single map entry key:value
      ['GBP', 'Pound sterling'],
    ]);
    
    currencies.forEach(function (value, key, map) {
      console.log(`${key}: ${value}`);
    })
    
// forEach with Set --------
    const currenciesUnique = new Set(['USD', 'GBP', 'USD', 'EUR']); // Shows unique values
    
    currenciesUnique.forEach(function (value, _, map) {
      console.log(`${value}`);
    })
    
    // Because the set.forEach does not have need for a key, the argument[key] is ommited by the underscore '_'.

Map method — .map(function(cur, i, arr))

The .map() method does the same as the forEach method, the important difference that it creates a new array.

Filter method — .filter(function(cur, i, arr))

The filter method creates a new array of the items that pass a certain check, for example:

const deposits = movements.filter(mov => mov > 0);
    // mov as the first argument refers to the currentValue!

Reduce method — .reduce(function(acc, cur, i, arr) {-operation-}, initialAccumulatorValue)

The reduce method takes all items of an array and reduces them into a single value.

The function itself takes 2 arguments: a callback function and the innitial starting value.

The function takes 4 arguments:

  1. the accumulator value,
  2. the current value,
  3. the current index,
  4. the entire array.

Examples:

const balance = movements.reduce((acc, cur) => acc + cur, 0);
    
const maxMovements = movements.reduce(function (acc, mov) {
        if (acc > mov)
            return acc;
        else
            return mov;
    }, movements[0]);

Find method — .find(function(cur, i, arr)

The find method returns the first item of an array that satisfies its conditions.

const firstWithdrawal = movements.find(mov => mov < 0)

findIndex

The findIndex returns the index of the found element, not the element itself.

Some method — .some(function(cur, i, arr))

Returns true or false based on wether any element of an array passes a condition.

var anyDeposits = movements.some(mov => mov > 0);
    console.log(anyDeposits) // returns boolean true
    //↑↑↑ Checks for any deposits (above 0) ----

Every method — .every(function(cur, i, arr))

Returns true or false based on whether all elements pass a condition.

const positiveEvery = [3, 4, 14, 132];
    console.log(positiveEvery.every(mov => mov > 0));
    //↑↑↑ Returns true ----

Flat / Flat map methods — .flat([depth]) / .flatMap()

The flat method is used to flatten a multilevel array, with the method parameter used to define the level of depth it should flatten to.

Example:

// Flat
    const accountMovements = accounts.map(acc => acc.movements).flat();
    console.log(accountMovements);

The flatMap method is used to flatten a map:

const movementsFlatMap = accounts.flatMap(acc => acc.movements).flat();
    console.log(movementsFlatMap);

Sort method — .sort(current, next)

The sort method sorts the elements of an array, based on the type of elements.

Sorting numbers with .sort()

Using sort to sort an array of numbers does not sort the numbers nummerically; this is because .sort() sorts items as a string.

Passing a compare callback solves this:

//---- ASCENDING --------
    const movementSortAsc = movements.sort((a, b) => {
      if (a > b) return 1; // KEEP ORDER
      if (a < b) return -1; // SWITCH ORDER
    });
    
    // SAME AS:
    const movementSortAsc = movements.sort((a, b) => a - b);
    console.log(`Asc order: ${movementSortAsc}`);
    
//---- DESCENDING --------
    const movementSortDesc = movements.sort((a, b) => {
      if (a > b) return -1; // SWITCH ORDER
      if (a < b) return 1; // KEEP ORDER
    });
    
    //SAME AS:
    const movementSortDesc = movements.sort((a, b) => b - a);
    console.log(`Desc order: ${movementSortDesc}`);

In short:

numbers.sort((current, next) => {
      Ascending or descending sorting order:
      return < 0 -> A, B (KEEP ORDER)
      return > 0 -> B, A (SWITCH ORDER)
    })

Creating and Filling Arrays

New arrays — new Array([size])

Creating a new empty array with a specified number of spaces:

const x = new Array(7);
    //=> Creates an array of 7 spaces

Fill method — .fill(placing value, startIndex, endIndex)

// fill array x ==-> mutates
    /* Looks like: ----
    x.fill([placing value], [startIndex], [endIndex]) */
    x.fill(1, 3, 5);
    console.log(x);
    
// Fill array with existing values:
    console.log(arr.fill(23, 2, 6));

From method — .from({length: [#]}, function())

The from method is used as an array innitiator, which takes a length argument as well as an input function:

const y = Array.from({ length: 7 }, () => 1);

The method can also be used to get 10 results of a dice throw:

const diceRolls10 = Array.from({length: 10}, () => Math.ceil(Math.random() * 6));

QuerySelectorAll & From method

The QuerySelectorAll returns a nodelist; a kind of array with all selected elements.

It is not a real array so it doesn't work with some methods.

Using Array.from, the nodelist from the DOM can be converted into a mutable array, without an array needing to be store elsewhere.

// Consider the movements of the banking app:
    const movementsUI = Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('.movements__value'));
    //↑↑↑ Creates an array of all movements__value elements----
    
// Alternative, doesn't allow chaining:
    const movementsUI2 = [...document.querySelectorAll('.movements__value')];
